docs.lead_paragraph: In the early 1990's, a small nonprofit hospital just outside Peekskill embarked on an expansion that would transform it from a homespun but antiquated local landmark into a region-wide medical center rated among the top 4 percent of the nation's hospitals. But the makeover of Peekskill Community Hospital into the Hudson Valley Hospital Center was also striking for other reasons.

headline.main: Hospital Is Haunted by History of Deals With Board Members

docs.abstract: Article reviews ethics questions raised about how Peekskill Community Hospital in New York transformed itself from homespun but antiquated local landmark into Hudson Valley Hospital Center, now rated amond top four percent of US hospitals; close ties between board members and those who helped carry out project, including architect and contractors, were not illegal because they were fully disclosed, but actions have come back to haunt former chairman Robert E Boyle, longtime fund-raiser for Gov George Pataki who is now executive director of New York-New Jersey Port Authority; Federal tax-fraud indictment against influential real estate lawyer Albert J Pirro Jr, husband of Westchester County district attorney, also alleges that Boyle owned major stake in Pirro company that sold medical office building to hospital for $1.5 million; Boyle was not charged and denies ownership in Pirro company, but hospital admits he managed renovation; he reportedly was paid $292,000; questionable dealings recounted; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Congressional staff member calls it ''the fine line between Paul Revere and Chicken Little.'' Treading that line is Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, who is using his travels around the state and his network television appearances to sound an alarm about the year 2000 computer problems, or ''the Y2K bug,'' a programming flaw that could cause some computers to shut down or go crazy on New Year's Day, potentially affecting everything from credit card transactions to air travel.

headline.main: In Travels, Dodd Spreads Word About Computer Flaw

docs.abstract: Sen Christopher Dodd uses travels around Connecticut and television appearances to spread alarm about year 2000 computer problems, treading line between Paul Revere and Chicken Little' (S)
docs.snippet: A Congressional staff member calls it ''the fine line between Paul Revere and Chicken Little.''    Treading that line is Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, who is using his travels around the state and his network television...

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE choreographer's return to New Jersey intersects, by chance, with another's departure, bringing out important issues in the dance world. Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company is back after Ms. Dorfman's yearlong sabbatical, while Septime Webre is leaving American Repertory Ballet to become artistic director of the Washington Ballet, which performs at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The parallels are skewed, perhaps, but they uncover the state's healthy profusion of possibilities. By June 1, Mr. Webre will be in another locale, and Ms. Dorfman's troupe has a new home in Madison. Both will be working with different dancers, he because he is moving, she because hers went elsewhere during her time off and she found others. Both their companies are to present new works in New Jersey in the next two weeks.

headline.main: Steps, Turns and Leaps in a Time of Transition for Two Companies

docs.abstract: Article on changes at Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company in Madison and American Repertory Ballet in New Brunswick, NJ; both companies will soon present new works with different dancers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS Nassau County's Republican leadership grapples with a health insurance scandal, a monumental budget shortfall and now a Federal challenge to the county's taxation system, local Democrats' political prospects seem brighter than they have been in decades. So why is Bruce Nyman standing at the plane door with a parachute strapped to his chest? Mr. Nyman, 47, the County Legislature's minority leader and the highest-profile figure in a fractured Democratic lineup, has been negotiating with officials in Long Beach, his hometown, about taking over as the city manager.

headline.main: Democrats Resurgent, but Nyman Steps Back

docs.abstract: Nassau County (NY) minority leader Bruce Nyman comments on scandals involving county's Republican leadership, need to strengthen Democratic Party leadership and possibility that he will take over as Long Beach city manager; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The un-Florio. It probably would not be Representative Frank Pallone Jr.'s first choice of campaign slogans. But Mr. Pallone, a six-term Democrat from Long Branch, is not discouraging anyone from anointing him the man to stop former Gov. Jim Florio in his quest to become the state's next senator.

headline.main: Florio? Oh, He's the Obstacle Standing in Pallone's Way.

docs.abstract: James Dao On Politics column explores possibility that Democratic New Jersey Repr Frank Pallone Jr could defeat former New Jersey Gov Jim Florio in next year's Democratic primary for US Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN this well-to-do county where the median price of a single-family house is $340,000 and the median income $61,861, the problem of hunger is often difficult to see. ''Especially in Westchester hunger wears many faces,'' said Christina Rohatynskyj, executive director of Food-Patch, a food bank in Millwood. ''You might look at your neighbors and never know.''

headline.main: The Many Faces Of Hunger; Even in an Affluent County, Many Have Little To Spend on Food After Paying the Rent

docs.abstract: Article on work of soup kitchens across Westchester County, NY, in trying to feed the hungry, particularly working poor, who often go unnoticed amid affluence; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attacking Gov. George E. Pataki directly for the first time in four years, hospitals and health care workers began a broadcast campaign today asserting that the Governor's proposed budget cuts would have dire consequences for health care, including hospital closings. The effort began with a 60-second radio advertisement in the New York metropolitan region and in Albany, and its sponsors say that in trying to raise a public outcry to defeat the cuts, they are prepared to expand the campaign to other parts of the state and to television, and to spend millions of dollars.

headline.main: Ads Attack Pataki's Plan On Hospitals

docs.abstract: New York hospitals and health care workers begin broadcast campaign asserting that Gov George E Pataki's budget cuts would have dire consequences for health care, including hospital closings; Pataki has called for $800 million in cuts, despite state budget surplus expected to top $2 billion; most of cuts would come in lower Medicaid payments to hospitals and nursing homes; campaign against Pataki is being led by Kenneth E Raske, president of Greater New York Hospital Association, and Dennis Rivera, head of 1199, National Health and Human Service Employees Union (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Banking Committee, breaking a deadlock over consumer privacy, approved legislation today that would lift Depression-era barriers between banks, securities firms and insurance companies. The panel voted 51 to 8 to adopt the complex measure and send it to the full House. The Clinton Administration has expressed strong support for the bipartisan bill but has threatened to veto financial overhaul legislation pending in the Senate.

headline.main: House Committee Approves Financial Overhaul Legislation

docs.abstract: House Banking Committee approves legislation that would lift barriers between banks, securities firms and insurance companies; Clinton Administration has expressed strong support for bipartisan bill; concerns have risen about how customer information will be shared among affiliates of big new companies, prompting lawmakers to work behind scenes on consumer privacy measure; lawmakers approve Rep James Leach's proposal to restrict sharing of some but not all information (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not since the demise of the Clinton Administration plan to overhaul the nation's health care system have Americans without health insurance, now more than 43 million people, received so much attention. With the post-impeachment Congress determined to demonstrate interest in domestic policy, and with lobbyists of all stripes trying to influence the health insurance debate, the long-overlooked uninsured are suddenly ''hot.''

headline.main: Help for the Uninsured May Rest in Tax Code

docs.abstract: Not since demise of Clinton Administration plan to overhaul the nation's health care system have Americans without health insurance, now more than 43 million people, received so much attention; rather than start a whole new Government insurance program or expand the old ones--Medicaid and the already overburdened Medicare--Republican leaders, a number of Democrats and an array of powerful interest groups are looking for solutions in tax system (M)
